Phillips, A., J. Marshall, and G. Monson. 1978. The Birds of Arizona The University of Arizona Press,
Tucson.

England, A. S. and W. F. Laudenslayer, Jr. 1993. Bendire's Thrasher (Toxostoma bendirei), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online:http://bna.birds.cornell.edu.ezproxy.prescott.edu:2048/bna/species/071
Madden, K. 2012. Expert Review for Western Governors Association. New Mexico Department of Fish and Game.
Gilman, M. F. 1915. A forty acre bird census at Sacaton, Arizona. Condor 17:86-90.
Rosenberg, K. V., R.D. Ohmart, W.C. Hunter, and B.W. Anderson. 1991. Birds of the lower Colorado River Valley University of Arizona Press, Tucson.

California Bird Species of Special Concern. 2008. W.D. Shuford and T. Gardall, eds. Western Field Ornithologists and California Department of Fish and Game. 78 pp. http://www.dfg.ca.gov/wildlife/nongame/ssc/birds.html
habitat_description: Bendire's Thrasher (Toxostoma bendirei) breeds in open grassland, desert scrub, shrubland, or woodland with scattered shrubs or trees (England and Laudenslayer 1993). May also utilize urban and agricultural areas that mimic natural habitat (Phillips et al. 1964, Rosenberg et al. 1991). Typically nests in shrubs, cacti, or trees (Ligon 1961) but will also use exotic vegetation around homes and agricultural fields (Gilman 1915). Little reported about habitats used in migration and winter; probably similar to those used for breeding (England and Laudenslayer 1993).
